articles.headline: Jury Convicts Man in Killing of 11 in Pittsburgh Synagogue
articles.snippet: Jurors will next hear arguments about whether the defendant, Robert Bowers, should be sentenced to death.
articles.abstract: Jurors will next hear arguments about whether the defendant, Robert Bowers, should be sentenced to death.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gunman who killed 11 worshipers in a Pittsburgh synagogue in October 2018 was found guilty on Friday of dozens of federal hate crimes and civil rights offenses, closing the first stage of a trial that may ultimately end in a death sentence.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Jon Moss

articles.headline: Hundreds Dead, 9 Arrested, and Many Questions in Migrant Wreck
articles.snippet: Greek authorities blamed smugglers for a disaster that may have been one of the worst of its kind. Critics say tougher policies are increasing the risks.
articles.abstract: Greek authorities blamed smugglers for a disaster that may have been one of the worst of its kind. Critics say tougher policies are increasing the risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the end of a long stretch of sandy beach, a weathered warehouse in the Greek port of Kalamata held the survivors of one of the worst shipwrecks in Europe in a decade.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Daniel Ellsberg, Who Leaked the Pentagon Papers, Is Dead at 92
articles.snippet: Deeply disturbed by the accounting of American deceit in Vietnam, he approached The New York Times. The disclosures that followed rocked the nation.
articles.abstract: Deeply disturbed by the accounting of American deceit in Vietnam, he approached The New York Times. The disclosures that followed rocked the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daniel Ellsberg, a military analyst who after experiencing a sobbing antiwar epiphany on a bathroom floor made the momentous decision in 1971 to disclose a secret history of American lies and deceit in Vietnam, what came to be known as the Pentagon Papers, died on Friday at his home in Kensington, Calif., in the Bay Area. He was 92.
articles.byline: By Robert D. McFadden

articles.headline: Meta to Lower Age for Users of Virtual Reality Headset to 10 From 13
articles.snippet: The company has reached out to regulators about its plans, which could set off privacy and safety concerns for parents and watchdogs.
articles.abstract: The company has reached out to regulators about its plans, which could set off privacy and safety concerns for parents and watchdogs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, plans to lower the recommended age for using its Quest headset to 10 from 13, the company said in a blog post on Friday, a move that could set off new privacy and safety concerns with parents and global watchdogs.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Adam Satariano and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Minneapolis Police Used Illegal, Abusive Practices for Years, Justice Dept. Finds
articles.snippet: The city said it would try to negotiate a court-enforced consent decree with the federal government that would require an overhaul of its police force.
articles.abstract: The city said it would try to negotiate a court-enforced consent decree with the federal government that would require an overhaul of its police force.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Friday that the Minneapolis police routinely discriminated against Black and Native American people, used deadly force without justification and trampled the First Amendment rights of protesters and journalists — damning findings that grew out of a multiyear investigation and may lead to a court-enforced overhaul.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño, Glenn Thrush, Mitch Smith and Dan Simmons

articles.headline: Famed Wine Store Sherry-Lehmann Faces Criminal Investigation
articles.snippet: A federal grand jury is scheduled to hear evidence about Sherry-Lehmann, whose customers and former employees have complained about missing wine.
articles.abstract: A federal grand jury is scheduled to hear evidence about Sherry-Lehmann, whose customers and former employees have complained about missing wine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has convened a federal grand jury as part of a criminal investigation into Sherry-Lehmann Wine & Spirits, the venerable New York City wine merchant, according to former employees who have been contacted by the authorities.
articles.byline: By James B. Stewart

articles.headline: The Business of Being Chris Christie
articles.snippet: Mr. Christie left the governor’s office in New Jersey and set out to, as he put it, “make money.” He successfully traded on his political profile — and on his ties to the man he now wants to defeat.
articles.abstract: Mr. Christie left the governor’s office in New Jersey and set out to, as he put it, “make money.” He successfully traded on his political profile — and on his ties to the man he now wants to defeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: As his second term as governor of New Jersey drew to a close in 2017, Chris Christie was characteristically blunt about his plans.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Alexandra Berzon

articles.headline: Uganda School Attack Leaves at Least 37 Dead
articles.snippet: The authorities attribute the attack, one of the deadliest in years, to the Allied Democratic Forces, an extremist group based in neighboring Congo.
articles.abstract: The authorities attribute the attack, one of the deadliest in years, to the Allied Democratic Forces, an extremist group based in neighboring Congo.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least 37 people were killed — many of them students — and eight others were wounded when militants with an extremist group attacked a secondary school in western Uganda, the authorities said on Saturday, in one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in the East African nation in years.
articles.byline: By Abdi Latif Dahir

articles.headline: A Year After Dobbs, Advocates Push in the States for a Right to Birth Control
articles.snippet: After Justice Clarence Thomas cast doubt on the Supreme Court decision that established a right to contraception, reproductive rights advocates are pressing for new protections at the state level.
articles.abstract: After Justice Clarence Thomas cast doubt on the Supreme Court decision that established a right to contraception, reproductive rights advocates are pressing for new protections at the state level.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year after Justice Clarence Thomas said the Supreme Court should reconsider whether the Constitution affords Americans a right to birth control, Democrats and reproductive rights advocates are laying the groundwork for state-by-state battles over access to contraception — an issue they hope to turn against Republicans in 2024.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Russia, Learning From Costly Mistakes, Shifts Battlefield Tactics
articles.snippet: Moscow’s forces remain uneven. But while bracing for a counteroffensive, they have improved discipline, coordination and air support, foreshadowing a changing war.
articles.abstract: Moscow’s forces remain uneven. But while bracing for a counteroffensive, they have improved discipline, coordination and air support, foreshadowing a changing war.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — The team of soldiers had been out of their Ukrainian armored personnel carrier for only a matter of minutes when the tree line in front of them erupted in Russian gunfire. The dozen or so soldiers, sent to reinforce a trench, found themselves pinned down for hours.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Julian E. Barnes and Natalia Yermak

articles.headline: Biden Administration Engages in Long-Shot Attempt for Saudi-Israel Deal
articles.snippet: The president and his aides are pressing an aggressive diplomatic effort as Riyadh makes significant demands in exchange for normalization, including a nuclear deal and a robust U.S. security pact.
articles.abstract: The president and his aides are pressing an aggressive diplomatic effort as Riyadh makes significant demands in exchange for normalization, including a nuclear deal and a robust U.S. security pact.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after his plane took off earlier this month from Riyadh, where he had held a lengthy meeting with Saudi Arabia’s crown prince, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken called a different Middle East leader, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman, Edward Wong and Vivian Nereim

articles.headline: Ron DeSantis Is Young, Has Little Kids and Wants America to Know It
articles.snippet: At 44, he is more than three decades younger than Donald Trump and Joe Biden. He is subtly playing up that age gap, even if his right-wing views leave him out of step with many younger voters.
articles.abstract: At 44, he is more than three decades younger than Donald Trump and Joe Biden. He is subtly playing up that age gap, even if his right-wing views leave him out of step with many younger voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: As top-tier presidential candidates go, Ron DeSantis is something of a rarity these days. He was born after the Vietnam War, he came of age when computers were common in American homes and he still has young children of his own, rather than enough grandchildren to fill a basketball team.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Nehamas and Ruth Igielnik

articles.headline: Why It Seems Everything We Knew About the Global Economy Is No Longer True
articles.snippet: While the world’s eyes were on the pandemic, China and the war in Ukraine, the paths to prosperity and shared interests have grown murkier.
articles.abstract: While the world’s eyes were on the pandemic, China and the war in Ukraine, the paths to prosperity and shared interests have grown murkier.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the world’s business and political leaders gathered in 2018 at the annual economic forum in Davos, the mood was jubilant. Growth in every major country was on an upswing. The global economy, declared Christine Lagarde, then the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, “is in a very sweet spot.”
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: He Went After Crypto Companies. Then Someone Came After Him.
articles.snippet: Kyle Roche was a rising star in the field of cryptocurrency law — until his career imploded. Who orchestrated his downfall?
articles.abstract: Kyle Roche was a rising star in the field of cryptocurrency law — until his career imploded. Who orchestrated his downfall?
articles.lead_paragraph: When he arrived in London in late January 2022, Kyle Roche was riding high. At just 34 years old, he had established himself as one of the biggest players in the burgeoning field of cryptocurrency litigation. He boasted a law firm bearing his name, lawsuits filed against more than a dozen crypto companies and a huge verdict against the man who claimed to have invented Bitcoin.
articles.byline: By John Carreyrou

articles.headline: Addicts Went in for Treatment. Instead They Were Enslaved.
articles.snippet: Families in Indonesia thought they were sending their sons to a rehab facility run by a powerful local official. Those who stayed there say it was a brutal human slavery operation.
articles.abstract: Families in Indonesia thought they were sending their sons to a rehab facility run by a powerful local official. Those who stayed there say it was a brutal human slavery operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Indonesian anti-corruption investigators began hunting for the powerful local official after they caught two of his aides taking a $40,000 bribe.
articles.byline: By Richard C. Paddock

articles.headline: Blinken Meets Xi as China and the U.S. Try to Rein in Tensions
articles.snippet: U.S. diplomats visited Beijing to try to ensure that competition “does not veer into conflict.” The talks pave the way for a possible Biden-Xi meeting.
articles.abstract: U.S. diplomats visited Beijing to try to ensure that competition “does not veer into conflict.” The talks pave the way for a possible Biden-Xi meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, on Monday in Beijing, as the two governments sought to pull relations out of a deep chill that has raised global concerns about the growing risk of a conflict between them.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and David Pierson

articles.headline: Where Housing Prices Have Crashed and Billions in Wealth Have Vanished
articles.snippet: In New Zealand, high interest rates have sent property prices sliding nearly 18 percent since November 2021.
articles.abstract: In New Zealand, high interest rates have sent property prices sliding nearly 18 percent since November 2021.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Wilson was hopeful when he put his three-bedroom house up for sale: Over a dozen would-be buyers came to the initial showing.
articles.byline: By Natasha Frost

articles.headline: Russia Sought to Kill Defector in Florida
articles.snippet: A failed plot to assassinate a C.I.A. spy in 2020 in part led to expulsions of the agency’s chief in Moscow and his Russian counterpart in Washington.
articles.abstract: A failed plot to assassinate a C.I.A. spy in 2020 in part led to expulsions of the agency’s chief in Moscow and his Russian counterpart in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has pursued enemies abroad, his intelligence operatives now appear prepared to cross a line that they previously avoided: trying to kill a valuable informant for the U.S. government on American soil.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Adam Goldman and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: In Argentina, Inflation Passes 100% (and the Restaurants Are Packed)
articles.snippet: Argentina’s financial crisis has a surprising side effect: a flourishing dining scene in Buenos Aires, as residents rush to spend pesos before they lose more value.
articles.abstract: Argentina’s financial crisis has a surprising side effect: a flourishing dining scene in Buenos Aires, as residents rush to spend pesos before they lose more value.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wine glasses clinked in an Art Nouveau culinary gem basking in its restored splendor. It was tasting night in the more than century-old coffeehouse turned restaurant at the old Buenos Aires zoo, as beet tartare, pan-seared squid and a perfect rib-eye floated out of the kitchen, chased by a velvety chocolate mousse.
articles.byline: By Natalie Alcoba and Sarah Pabst

articles.headline: G.O.P. Targets Researchers Who Study Disinformation Ahead of 2024 Election
articles.snippet: A legal campaign against universities and think tanks seeks to undermine the fight against false claims about elections, vaccines and other hot political topics.
articles.abstract: A legal campaign against universities and think tanks seeks to undermine the fight against false claims about elections, vaccines and other hot political topics.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Capitol Hill and in the courts, Republican lawmakers and activists are mounting a sweeping legal campaign against universities, think tanks and private companies that study the spread of disinformation, accusing them of colluding with the government to suppress conservative speech online.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Sheera Frenkel
